item.title: Personal Academic Website with Hugo Academic
item.description:
🎓 Why Do Researchers Need a Personal Website?

In the era of digital science and open access, more and more researchers are creating personal websites to showcase their projects, publications, biographies, and courses in one convenient space. A personal website is not just a business card — it’s a powerful tool for:

  • Academic communication;
  • Sharing research results and presentations;
  • Building an academic portfolio;
  • Promoting your research and networking with colleagues.

⚙️ Why Hugo Academic?

Hugo Academic (now called Hugo Scholar) is a professional template built on the Hugo static site generator, designed specifically for researchers, educators, and students.

Key advantages of Hugo Academic:

  • 📄 Ready-made templates for bios, CVs, publications, courses, projects, and blogs;
  • 🌐 Multilingual support and SEO optimization;
  • 📊 Integration with Google Scholar, ORCID, GitHub, Twitter, and other services;
  • 📚 Display of bibliographies, DOIs, preprints, and publication metadata;
  • ⚡️ Fast load times and offline access due to its static site nature.

🧩 What Can You Include on the Website?

A Hugo Academic site is organized into sections, each serving a specific content type. A researcher can use the following sections:

  • Biography: photo, brief description of interests, academic background;
  • Education and Experience: alma mater, internships, teaching roles;
  • Publications: journal articles, conferences, book chapters, preprints;
  • Projects: current research or IT initiatives;
  • Courses: student materials, lecture links, assignments;
  • Blog: short notes on research, literature reviews, updates;
  • Contact: email, social media, maps, contact forms.

🌍 Who Is It For?

  • 🎓 Early-career researchers — to showcase their first works and internships;
  • 📚 Educators — to host course materials, schedules, and resources;
  • 🔬 Graduate and postgraduate students — to build portfolios and attract attention to their research;
  • 🧠 Professors and researchers — to organize their scholarly output.

🧭 Conclusion

Creating a website with Hugo Academic is a modern and professional way to present yourself as a researcher. It minimizes technical hurdles, supports all essential academic functions, and helps build a strong digital presence in the scientific community. A well-structured site shows that you not only publish papers but also know how to communicate your work effectively.

If you aim to make your academic career more visible, Hugo Academic is an excellent place to start.

item.title: Working with Bibliography
item.description:
📚 What Is a Bibliography?

A bibliography is a structured list of sources used in preparing an academic text. It is formatted according to established standards (GOST, APA, MLA, IEEE, etc.) and serves the following purposes:

  • Confirming citations and borrowed ideas;
  • Guiding readers to source materials;
  • Demonstrating the depth of research on the topic.

A properly formatted bibliography is an essential part of any academic, scholarly, or research work.

🛠 How Is a Bibliography Created?

The process includes several steps:

  1. Collecting sources — articles, books, dissertations, web materials, standards, etc.;
  2. Formalizing descriptions — formatting each source according to citation rules;
  3. Sorting — alphabetically, by source type, or in the order of citation;
  4. In-text citation — linking each source to relevant parts of the main text.

🔧 Tools for Managing Sources

Efficient bibliography management often relies on specialized tools:

📦 Bibliography Managers:

  • Zotero — a user-friendly tool with export options for various formats;
  • Mendeley — widely used in natural sciences;
  • JabRef — ideal for working with BibTeX databases in LaTeX;
  • EndNote — a professional solution for large-scale research projects.

🧮 Markup Systems:

  • BibTeX/BibLaTeX — used with LaTeX to automatically cite and generate bibliographies;
  • Citation plugins — available for Word, Google Docs, Overleaf, integrated with Zotero and Mendeley.

📐 Citation Formats

Different citation systems require different formatting approaches:

  • GOST — used in Russia, requires full details (author, title, source, year, publisher, pages);
  • APA — common in psychology and social sciences, emphasizes publication date;
  • IEEE — used in engineering and computer science;
  • MLA — used in the humanities, includes author and page references.

📌 Helpful Tips

  • 📑 Record sources as soon as you use them;
  • 🔍 Verify the accuracy and reliability of each link;
  • 📚 For online materials, save the access date;
  • 🧩 Maintain consistent citation style throughout your work;
  • 📝 Don’t forget about self-citation and academic integrity.

🧭 Conclusion

A bibliography is not just a formality — it reflects your academic rigor. Proper source documentation makes writing easier, boosts credibility, and enhances the professionalism of your text. Modern tools automate much of the process — the key is to learn how to use them effectively.

item.title: Markup Languages. LaTeX
item.description:
🧾 What Are Markup Languages?

Markup languages are systems that allow users to describe the structure and formatting of text. They are used to prepare documents, web pages, scientific reports, and presentations.

Unlike visual text editors (WYSIWYG), markup relies on tags and commands that define the layout and content structure.

Examples of markup languages include:

  • HTML (for web pages),
  • Markdown (for lightweight formatting),
  • XML (for data representation),
  • LaTeX (for scientific and technical documents).

✒️ What Is LaTeX?

LaTeX (pronounced “Lah-tech”) is a markup language and typesetting system designed for producing scientific, technical, and mathematical documents. It is based on the TeX system developed by Donald Knuth.

LaTeX allows you to create high-quality documents with precise control over the formatting of equations, tables, figures, and text structure.

🧠 Why Is LaTeX Important?

LaTeX is indispensable in the academic world, especially in the following cases:

  • 📐 Preparing theses, dissertations, papers, and reports;
  • 🧮 Writing complex mathematical expressions and formulas;
  • 📄 Creating presentations, diagrams, graphs, and tables;
  • 🔍 Meeting strict style, bibliography, and structural requirements.

🛠 Key Features of LaTeX

  • Command-based structure (\section{}, \textbf{}, \frac{}, etc.);
  • Mathematical formatting: equations can be inline or displayed;
  • Automatic generation of table of contents, bibliography, numbering of formulas and figures;
  • Flexible class and package system for customization;
  • Support for journal and conference publication standards.

📘 Example Use Cases

  • Physicists and mathematicians use LaTeX to publish formula-heavy research;
  • Students format term papers and theses according to official standards;
  • Universities publish lecture materials and manuals;
  • Scientific software developers write documentation and technical reports.

📦 Advantages and Disadvantages

Advantages:

  • High print quality and professional typesetting;
  • Clear separation of content structure and styling;
  • Automation and template reuse;
  • Universal and cross-platform compatibility.

Disadvantages:

  • Requires time to learn the syntax;
  • No visual editing interface (though Overleaf provides one);
  • Syntax errors can be hard to debug.

🧭 Conclusion

LaTeX is a powerful tool for those who value precision, structure, and professional text formatting. Despite its learning curve, mastering LaTeX is worthwhile for anyone involved in academic or technical writing. It has become the de facto standard in the scientific community, especially in the natural and technical sciences.
